eda_steps.step_description: Comprehensive analysis of missing data patterns across all features to identify data quality issues and guide imputation strategies.
step_insights: 13.4% missing values in time_phoneuse_hours feature, indicating potential data collection issues
0.7% missing values in most driving behavior features, suggesting systematic missing patterns for specific drivers
No missing values in target variable (collisions) ensures reliable model training

eda_steps.step_description: Examination of collision frequency distribution to understand class imbalance and inform sampling strategies.
step_insights: Severe class imbalance: 95.2% no collisions, 4.6% one collision, 0.2% two collisions
Class imbalance requires specialized handling (stratified sampling, class weights, or resampling)
Low collision frequency makes precision-recall metrics more appropriate than accuracy

eda_steps.step_description: Analysis of distribution patterns for numerical driving behavior features to identify skewness and scaling requirements.
step_insights: Most features are heavily right-skewed, requiring log transformation or other normalization
Wide range of values across features (e.g., miles: 0-309K, drive_hours: 0-13K) necessitates feature scaling
Some features have zero-inflated distributions, indicating many drivers with minimal activity in certain categories

eda_steps.step_description: Analysis of categorical variable distributions, focusing on driver ID uniqueness and temporal patterns.
step_insights: Driver ID has very high cardinality (7,663 unique values) with minimal repetition
Month distribution shows relatively even temporal spread across the year
High driver ID cardinality suggests minimal longitudinal data per driver

eda_steps.step_description: Correlation matrix analysis to identify relationships between features and target variable for feature selection.
step_insights: Count_trip shows strongest correlation with collisions (0.246), indicating trip frequency as key predictor
Strong multicollinearity between driving behavior features (r>0.98 between miles, drive_hours, brakes)
Maximum speed shows negative correlation with collisions (-0.065), suggesting cautious drivers

eda_steps.step_description: IQR-based outlier detection to identify extreme values that may impact model performance and require treatment.
step_insights: Time_speeding_hours has highest outlier percentage (17.0%), indicating extreme speeding behavior in some drivers
Most driving behavior features have 9-12% outliers, suggesting diverse driving patterns
Phone use and maximum speed features have no outliers, indicating controlled ranges

eda_steps.step_description: Box plot analysis of the strongest predictor (count_trip) across different collision classes to understand predictive patterns.
step_insights: Clear progressive relationship: higher trip counts associated with more collisions (mean: 8.1, 16.4, 26.0)
Drivers with 2 collisions show consistently high trip counts (18-30 trips), indicating frequency risk
Strong separation between collision classes suggests count_trip as powerful predictor

dataset_description: Vehicle collision prediction dataset containing telematic data from 7,667 driver-month records with 13 features. The dataset includes driving behavior metrics (trips, miles, braking, acceleration), risk indicators (speeding, phone use), and environmental factors (highway driving, night driving) to predict collision events.

columns.name: driver_id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each driver, highly categorical with minimal repetition
columns.additional_information: 7,663 unique driver IDs with only 4 drivers appearing twice, indicating predominantly single-month records per driver

columns.name: month
columns.description: Month of data collection from Jan-22 to Dec-22, showing temporal distribution
columns.additional_information: 12 unique months with relatively even distribution (614-680 records per month), useful for seasonal analysis

columns.name: count_trip
columns.description: Number of trips taken by driver in the month, strongest predictor of collisions
columns.additional_information: Range: 1-31 trips, mean: 8.5, shows clear correlation with collision risk (r=0.246)

columns.name: miles
columns.description: Total miles driven during the month, highly correlated with driving exposure
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-309K miles, mean: 508, heavily right-skewed distribution requiring transformation

columns.name: drive_hours
columns.description: Total driving hours in the month, proxy for exposure time
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-13K hours, mean: 25, strong correlation with miles (r=0.996) indicating potential multicollinearity

columns.name: count_brakes
columns.description: Number of hard braking events, indicator of aggressive or reactive driving behavior
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-90K events, mean: 118, high correlation with drive time suggesting exposure-dependent metric

columns.name: count_accelarations
columns.description: Number of hard acceleration events, measure of aggressive driving behavior
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-90K events, mean: 119, nearly identical distribution to braking events (r=1.0)

columns.name: time_speeding_hours
columns.description: Hours spent speeding above limits, direct risk behavior indicator
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-51 hours, mean: 0.09, highly skewed with 17% outliers indicating extreme speeding in some drivers

columns.name: time_phoneuse_hours
columns.description: Hours of phone use while driving, distracted driving metric with significant missing values
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-2.2 hours, mean: 1.1, 13.4% missing values requiring imputation strategy

columns.name: highway_miles
columns.description: Miles driven on highways, indicating driving environment type
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-96K miles, mean: 105, subset of total miles with similar distribution patterns

columns.name: night_drive_hrs
columns.description: Hours of night driving, environmental risk factor
columns.additional_information: Range: 0-106 hours, mean: 0.12, low average with 2.5% outliers indicating some high night-driving activity

columns.name: maximum_speed
columns.description: Maximum speed reached during the month, driving intensity indicator
columns.additional_information: Range: 60-90 mph, mean: 78, no outliers suggesting data capping, negative correlation with collisions

columns.name: collisions
columns.description: Number of collisions in the month (0, 1, or 2), target variable for prediction
columns.additional_information: Severe class imbalance: 95.2% no collisions, 4.6% one collision, 0.2% two collisions - requires specialized handling

eda_summary: The vehicle collision prediction dataset reveals a challenging but workable prediction problem. Key challenges include severe class imbalance (95.2% no collisions), significant missing values in phone use data (13.4%), and strong multicollinearity among driving exposure metrics. The strongest predictive signal comes from trip frequency (count_trip, r=0.246), showing clear progression across collision classes. Most features are heavily right-skewed with substantial outliers, requiring robust preprocessing. The high driver ID cardinality with minimal repetition indicates cross-sectional rather than longitudinal data. Successful modeling will require careful handling of class imbalance, feature selection to address multicollinearity, appropriate missing value imputation, and scaling/transformation of skewed features. The clear relationship between driving activity levels and collision risk suggests good potential for predictive modeling despite the challenges.
